answers.answer: Warts are very stubborn.  I've seen patients that had them for 6+ years!  Typically, i cut these lesions out (down to  the basement layer of your skin) and perform a rotation of the adjacent skin to allow for closure.  This works well and has very little recurrence rate.  I would consider having this done by someone who has the training to do so.As for the nail whiteness:  sounds like yeast.  You can go to a podiatrist to get a dermabrasion of the nail to remove most of the yeast.  Then, topical ketoconazole 2% cream (prescription) applied twice daily for 4 weeks should do the trick.  The numbness could stem from a drug reaction, vit b12 deficiency, or diabetes.  It's difficult to assess without seeing you.  I would recommend getting this checked out by your podiatrist.

question: I've had Plantar Warts for years now.  I went to a podiatrist who started out trying to get rid of them with acid and scraping but that started being too painful.  She tried freezing them but it only worked superficially.  So she did surgery.  She put me out and I think that she used a laser to cut them out.  I have two large ones on the the side of my right foot and a cluster near one on the bottom.  Sure enough, 6 mo later they came back.  I've just been filing them down and moisturizing to keep them from snagging my hose.  I read somewhere that they should have gone away on their own after a while.  My question is are they a symptom of something else going on?  I'm having other issues that seem to me to be autoimmune in nature or neuropathic.  I have also developed white areas under some of my toenails. They are not powdery.  And for the last 10 years I've had numbness in the second toe of both feet and burning on the bottom (like I just walked across a hot sidewalk).  Thank you for your time.
title: Plantar Warts
